Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the father should purchase it
Expectation2: Teach children about Jewish traditions, values, and history
Situation2: An upcoming holiday is near, and the children still need to learn the related blessings.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, the promise I’d made to my son echoing in my mind. He’d been saving up, counting the days until I would buy him the Nintendo he wanted so badly. I wanted to give him that joy, to show him that I could provide, that I could keep my word as a father. But as I glanced at the calendar, I saw the holiday approaching—one of the most important in our tradition. My own father had always made sure I knew the blessings, the stories, the meaning behind every ritual. I felt the weight of that legacy pressing on me. My son’s eyes sparkled with excitement for the game, but I worried he was missing the deeper spark, the connection to our heritage. Money was tight, and time even tighter. I felt torn, pulled between the need to provide and the need to teach, between the world he wanted and the world I wanted him to inherit. My heart ached as I realized I couldn’t give him both, at least not right now.
